effective_dosage: Intermittent supplementation (one, two, or three times a week on non-consecutive days); total weekly dose of elemental iron varied.
study_duration: Varies by study (not specified in abstract).

study_goal: To assess the effects of intermittent oral iron supplementation, alone or with other nutrients, on anaemia and related impairments in menstruating women, compared to no intervention, placebo, or daily supplementation.
results_summary: Intermittent iron supplementation reduced anaemia risk and improved haemoglobin and ferritin levels compared to no intervention or placebo, but was less effective than daily supplementation in preventing anaemia. Effects were consistent across different dosages, durations, and baseline anaemia levels, with unclear impacts on morbidity, side effects, and adherence.
population_specificity: Menstruating women (post-menarche, pre-menopause, non-pregnant, non-lactating, without conditions impeding menstruation).
effective_dosage: 1-3 times weekly (non-consecutive days), with weekly elemental iron doses varying (some trials used ≤60 mg/week, others >60 mg/week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety of hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) collection methods (BM vs. PBSC) in pediatric donors, including factors like pain, transfusion risk, and iron supplementation.
results_summary: The study found significant differences between BM and PBSC donors regarding pain, transfusion, hospital stay, and iron supplementation, with older children reporting more pain after BM harvest. Severe adverse events were rare, with one case of pneumothorax after CVC placement for PBSC collection.
population_specificity: Pediatric donors (children) undergoing HSC collection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of iron supplementation, among other micronutrients, in addressing widespread deficiencies and improving health outcomes.
results_summary: The study highlights that targeted iron/folate supplementation, along with other fortification strategies, is effective in addressing multiple micronutrient deficiencies, particularly in developing countries. Iron supplementation is noted as part of a broader approach to improving micronutrient malnutrition.
population_specificity: General populations in industrialized and developing countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of iron intake on cognitive development and function in infants, children, and adolescents through a systematic review of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found a modest positive effect of iron supplementation on cognition and psychomotor outcomes in anemic infants and children after at least 2 months of supplementation, though heterogeneity and risk of bias were noted.
population_specificity: Infants, children, and adolescents up to 18 years of age, particularly those with anemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the causes, diagnosis, and management of iron deficiency anemia (IDA) in pregnancy, including the effectiveness and safety of iron supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that iron supplementation is effective in preventing and treating IDA in pregnancy, reducing maternal and perinatal morbidity and mortality. Oral iron is preferred over intravenous therapy, and weekly supplementation is recommended for menstruating women, while daily supplementation is advised during pregnancy and postpartum.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, menstruating women (including adolescents), and postpartum women.
effective_dosage: Weekly for menstruating women, daily during pregnancy and postpartum (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: To compare the reticulocyte responses of once-per-week versus 3-times-a-week erythropoietin (EPO) dosing in preterm infants, with iron supplementation as part of the treatment regimen.
results_summary: Both dosing schedules of EPO, combined with iron supplementation, increased absolute reticulocyte counts (ARCs) and maintained stable hematocrit levels in preterm infants, with no significant differences between the groups. No adverse effects were noted for either dosing schedule.
population_specificity: Preterm infants weighing ≤ 1500 g and ≥ 7 days of age.
effective_dosage: Iron dosage not specified; EPO was administered at 1200 U/kg once per week or 400 U/kg 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sodium iron ethylenediaminetetraacetate (NaFeEDTA) and ferrous sulfate on iron bioavailability and oxidative stress in anemic pregnant women.
results_summary: Both iron forms significantly improved hematologic indicators (Hb, plasma iron, ferritin) and oxidative stress parameters (GSH-Px, MDA), with NaFeEDTA showing superior efficacy in plasma iron, ferritin, and GSH-Px activity compared to ferrous sulfate.
population_specificity: Anemic pregnant women (80 ≤ Hb <110 g/L)
effective_dosage: 60 mg iron daily as ferrous sulfate or NaFeEDTA

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the benefits and risks of iron supplementation and biofortification strategies to address iron deficiency and its health impacts.
results_summary: Iron deficiency adversely affects growth and immune function, but supplementation may exacerbate infections. Biofortification of crops with iron and prebiotics could improve health, while reducing phytic acid might be less beneficial in regions with endemic infections.
population_specificity: General population, with implications for both developed and developing countries.

study_goal: To determine the effect of prophylactic iron supplementation on iron status and birth outcomes among nonanemic pregnant women.
results_summary: Iron supplementation significantly reduced the incidence of iron deficiency at delivery compared to placebo, but there were no significant differences in maternal hemoglobin, ferritin concentrations, or infant birth outcomes between the groups.
population_specificity: Nonanemic pregnant women with hemoglobin > 110 g/L, serum ferritin > 12 µg/L, and gestational age < 20 weeks.
effective_dosage: 60 mg elemental iron (as ferrous sulfate) daily until delivery.
study_duration: From enrollment (<20 weeks gestation) until delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of iron and folic acid supplementation programs during pregnancy and explore potential benefits of multiple-micronutrient supplementation or pre-conception interventions.
results_summary: The study found that current supplementation programs have only modest effects on increasing birth weight, and the additional advantages of multiple-micronutrient supplementation remain unclear.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, women of reproductive age, and young children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the relationship between hepcidin, erythropoietin, and iron status in low-birth-weight infants, comparing iron-replete and iron-deficient groups.
results_summary: Iron supplementation significantly increased hepcidin levels and decreased erythropoietin, with hepcidin closely correlated with iron status markers. The study suggests hepcidin may be a useful indicator of iron stores in infants.
population_specificity: Low-birth-weight infants (285 participants).
study_duration: From 6 weeks to 6 months of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maternal supplementation with multi-micronutrients, iron-folic acid, or folic acid alone during pregnancy on child growth outcomes in the first 30 months of life.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in stunting, underweight, wasting, or growth Z-scores among children whose mothers received multi-micronutrients, iron-folic acid, or folic acid alone during pregnancy. The pooled prevalence of stunting was slightly lower in the multi-micronutrient group (12.1%) compared to the iron-folic acid (14.9%) and folic acid (13.5%) groups, but the differences were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their children (n=1388 newborns) followed from birth to 30 months of age.
effective_dosage: Daily supplementation during pregnancy (specific amounts not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: Pregnancy period (exact duration not specified in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of oral versus intravenous iron supplementation, particularly in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), and assess whether lower oral doses could be as effective as higher doses with fewer side effects.
results_summary: Both IV and oral iron effectively raised hemoglobin levels in iron-deficiency anemia, with no evidence that IV iron works faster. Low-dose oral iron showed comparable efficacy to higher doses but with fewer side effects, and oral iron did not worsen IBD symptoms.
population_specificity: Patients with iron-deficiency anemia, particularly those with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
effective_dosage: One ferrous sulfate tablet per day (low-dose oral iron).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the incidence of anemia and iron deficiency between infants who received exclusive breastfeeding (EBF) up to 6 months and those who did not.
results_summary: The study found a higher prevalence of anemia in non-EBF infants (12.8%) compared to EBF infants (4.2%), with most anemia cases in the non-EBF group linked to iron deficiency. However, the differences in hematocrit and red blood cell indices were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 6-month-old infants visiting well-child clinics at QSNICH and Ramathibodi Hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the iron balance and serum status in Polish vegetarian children compared to omnivorous children.
results_summary: The study found that iron markers in vegetarian children were within the physiological range, similar to omnivorous children, indicating sufficient iron status despite dietary restrictions. No significant adverse effects or deficiencies related to iron were reported.
population_specificity: Polish children aged 5-11 years, including 32 vegetarians and 18 omnivores.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a single preoperative dose of erythropoietin and iron sucrose could reduce perioperative transfusion requirements in anemic patients undergoing valvular heart surgery.
results_summary: The study found that the erythropoietin and iron group had significantly fewer transfusions (59% vs. 86%) and required fewer units of packed erythrocytes (1.0 vs. 3.3 units/patient). Reticulocyte counts were also significantly higher in the treatment group postoperatively.
population_specificity: Anemic patients undergoing valvular heart surgery.
effective_dosage: 200 mg iron sucrose intravenously, administered once 1 day before surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of iron supplementation, particularly in regions with high malaria and infection prevalence, and to assess methods for screening iron deficiency.
results_summary: The study found that iron supplementation poses safety concerns in malaria-endemic areas, especially where treatment access is limited, but remains effective for treating iron deficiency when properly targeted. Iron deficiency screening methods lack consensus, and supplements are least desirable for prevention in infants and children.
population_specificity: Populations in malaria-endemic regions, particularly infants and children.
interactions: Malaria and other infections mentioned as potential interactions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical usefulness of hepcidin assessment in analyzing iron status and determining the ferritin cut-off for iron supplementation in young non-anemic athletes.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in hepcidin levels between athletes with ferritin levels below 15 microg/L and those in the 15-30 microg/L range, but significant differences between the 15-30 microg/L and 30-50 microg/L groups. It suggests ferritin levels below 30 microg/L indicate asymptomatic iron deficiency and proposes 30 microg/L as the cut-off for supplementation.
population_specificity: Young non-anemic athletes (50 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of anaemia and iron deficiency in HIV-infected pregnant women, assessing the role of infections, inflammation, and micronutrient status.
results_summary: The study found that parasitic infections, low vitamin D, high erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and low CD4 T-cell counts were key predictors of anaemia and iron deficiency, suggesting that iron supplementation alone may not fully address anaemia in this population.
population_specificity: HIV-infected pregnant women in Tanzania.
study_duration: Follow-up period not explicitly stated, but study conducted from 1995-1997.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and efficacy of iron supplementation in treating anemia in elderly patients undergoing hip or knee surgery.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that iron supplementation increased hemoglobin levels but showed no significant difference in hospital stay, morbidity, mortality, infection rate, transfusion needs, or adverse effects compared to no treatment.
population_specificity: Elderly patients undergoing hip or knee surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of iron supplementation on malaria risk and mortality in children, particularly in malaria-endemic regions.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in clinical malaria or death between iron supplementation and placebo when regular malaria surveillance and treatment were provided. Iron with antimalarial treatment significantly reduced malaria, and iron supplementation did not increase parasitological failure or deaths during acute malaria episodes.
population_specificity: Children below 18 years of age in hypoendemic to holoendemic malaria regions.
interactions: Iron with antimalarial treatment reduced malaria; iron and folic acid supplementation showed mixed results for severe malaria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intravenous iron supplementation could protect against acute mountain sickness (AMS) by influencing cellular oxygen sensing pathways.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in absolute AMS scores between the iron and placebo groups, but the iron group showed a 65% smaller mean increase in AMS score, which correlated negatively with ferritin changes. Hematocrit and arterial oxygen saturation were unaffected by iron.
population_specificity: 24 healthy sea-level residents ascending to high altitude (4340 m).
effective_dosage: 200 mg of intravenous iron(III)-hydroxide sucrose, single dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the prevalence, risk factors, and effects of geophagy in pregnancy (GiP) and recommend interventions to reduce GiP, particularly focusing on micronutrient deficiencies like iron.
results_summary: The study found that geophagy in pregnancy is prevalent (up to 84% in some regions) and associated with micronutrient deficiencies, including iron, but also poses risks like reduced bioavailability of nutrients and exposure to geohelminths and heavy metals. It recommends discouraging geophagy and strengthening iron supplementation and fortification programs.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, particularly in African countries like Nigeria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a multi-micronutrient-fortified beverage, including iron, improved physical performance and micronutrient status in school-age children.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in iron status, aerobic capacity, and endurance in children receiving the fortified beverage compared to placebo and control groups. These changes were statistically significant (P < 0.05).
population_specificity: Clinically healthy school-age children (7–10.5 years) with height- and weight-for-age Z-scores between 0 and ≥ -3.
effective_dosage: 40 g fortified choco-malt beverage powder daily (containing iron among 19 vitamins and minerals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of iron dysregulation (including deficiency and iron-restricted erythropoiesis) in anemia among children with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and the effectiveness of iron supplementation alongside erythropoietin-stimulating agents (ESAs).
results_summary: The study found that iron dysregulation is a primary cause of anemia in children with CKD, and iron supplementation combined with ESAs can effectively treat this condition. However, hyporesponsiveness to ESA therapy is common, and optimal hemoglobin targets for children remain unclear.
population_specificity: Children with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize qualitative data on the experiences and perceptions of iron supplementation among women of reproductive age and health service providers worldwide.
results_summary: The study identified seven key domains influencing iron supplementation, including cultural norms, socio-economic factors, education, and health care access. It highlighted 16 sub-domains, emphasizing the need for policy adaptation to local contexts.
population_specificity: Women of reproductive age and health service providers across 17 countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of oxidative stress markers, including non-protein-bound iron (NPBI), in Rett syndrome (RTT) and assess the impact of omega-3 PUFAs on these markers.
results_summary: Higher oxidative stress markers (including NPBI) were associated with more severe RTT phenotypes and early disease stages. Omega-3 PUFAs supplementation reduced oxidative stress markers and improved clinical severity scores.
population_specificity: 113 Rett syndrome patients and healthy controls, with a subset of 42 typical RTT patients receiving omega-3 PUFAs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of antihelminthic treatment combined with iron folate supplementation on reducing anemia prevalence in pregnant women.
results_summary: The study found that iron folate supplementation, alongside antihelminthic treatment, significantly reduced anemia prevalence at term and postpartum, with higher hemoglobin levels in the treatment group compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in Rufiji district, Tanzania, with high prevalence of intestinal parasites.
effective_dosage: 36 mg iron and 5 mg folate daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether maternal iron supplementation, in combination with folic acid and other micronutrients, influenced offspring insulin resistance, particularly in vitamin B-12 deficient mothers.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of iron supplementation (alone or combined with folic acid and zinc) on offspring insulin resistance, regardless of maternal vitamin B-12 status. Maternal vitamin B-12 deficiency was associated with increased insulin resistance in offspring, but supplementation did not mitigate this effect.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in a population with high vitamin B-12 deficiency prevalence and their offspring assessed at 6-8 years of age.
effective_dosage: Not specified (combined with folic acid and/or zinc in some groups).
study_duration: Supplementation during pregnancy (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether micronutrient supplementation, including iron, could improve immune function and reduce common infections in type 2 diabetic outpatients.
results_summary: The study found that iron levels increased in the supplementation group, alongside improved immune markers and reduced incidence of infections such as upper respiratory infections and urinary tract infections.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic outpatients (n=196)

study_goal: The researchers were evaluating the role of iron supplementation as part of the symptomatic treatment for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).
results_summary: The abstract mentions iron supplementation as part of empirical and symptomatic treatment for PNH, but no specific results regarding its effects are provided.
population_specificity: Patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether iron supplementation shortens auditory brainstem response (ABR) latencies in marginally low birth weight (MLBW) infants.
results_summary: Iron supplementation did not significantly improve ABR latencies in MLBW infants, and iron-deficient infants showed no prolonged ABR latencies. Central conduction time (CCT) was higher in the 2 mg group, but this difference was not correlated with iron intake or status.
population_specificity: Healthy marginally low birth weight (MLBW) infants (2000-2500 g).
study_duration: From 6 weeks to 6 months of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate factors associated with iron supplementation receipt among children and mothers in rural India and assess the adequacy of public iron distribution.
results_summary: The study found that iron supplementation rates were low (41.5% of children, 3.7% nationally), with disparities linked to wealth, sex, maternal health factors, and access to services. Public distribution was inadequate, highlighting implementation gaps in anemia control policies.
population_specificity: Rural children (aged 12-23 months) and their mothers in Karnataka, India, and nationally representative rural data from NFHS-3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Sprinkles, Foodlets, and Drops in improving iron status and other micronutrient deficiencies among Iranian infants.
results_summary: Iron status improved with all treatments, with Drops showing significantly greater changes in hemoglobin and serum ferritin. However, changes in anemia prevalence did not differ across groups.
population_specificity: Iranian infants aged 6-18 months living in an urban district.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether universal iron supplementation or targeted screening and treatment was more effective in reducing anemia prevalence among low-income postpartum women.
results_summary: Universal iron supplementation (65 mg/d for two months) significantly improved hemoglobin levels and reduced anemia prevalence (22.5%) compared to selective screening (34%) and universal screening with treatment (43%).
population_specificity: Low-income postpartum women in Mississippi.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether teff flour-enriched bread could improve iron bioavailability compared to control bread and iron supplements in nonpregnant women.
results_summary: Teff bread provided significantly more iron (7.6mg) than control bread (5.1mg). Adding phytase (TB+P2) resulted in the smallest decline in serum iron levels and higher iron absorption compared to other bread groups.
population_specificity: Nonpregnant women aged 20-50 years with hemoglobin levels of 9.5-14.0 g/dL.
effective_dosage: Three or four slices of teff bread (specific iron content not detailed).
study_duration: Single intervention with blood samples taken before and 180-210 minutes after consumption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Helicobacter pylori eradication therapy improves the response to oral iron supplementation in pregnant women with iron deficiency anaemia (IDA).
results_summary: The study found that H. pylori eradication therapy significantly improved haematological parameters and serum iron profile compared to placebo in pregnant women with IDA after 6 weeks of oral iron and folic acid supplementation.
population_specificity: Pregnant women between 14-30 weeks gestation with mild to moderate IDA and H. pylori infection.
effective_dosage: Therapeutic doses of iron and folic acid (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of multiple micronutrient supplementation versus iron and folic acid supplementation on pregnancy outcomes in developing countries.
results_summary: Multiple micronutrient supplementation was more effective than iron and folic acid in reducing low birth weight and small size for gestational age but showed no overall effect on perinatal mortality, with heterogeneity linked to maternal education and gestational age at supplementation initiation.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in developing countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maternal nutritional status modifies the birthweight response to prenatal multiple micronutrient (MMN) supplementation, including iron, compared to iron/folic acid alone.
results_summary: MMN supplementation increased mean birthweight by 33g in women with higher mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) and reduced low birthweight by 21%, but maternal height did not modify the response.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in Indonesia participating in the Supplementation with Multiple Micronutrient Intervention Trial.
study_duration: Duration of pregnancy (exact length not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a prolonged-release ferrous sulphate formulation (V0355) was non-inferior to Ferrograd® in treating iron deficiency anaemia in women, while also evaluating gastrointestinal tolerance.
results_summary: V0355 was found to be non-inferior to Ferrograd® in increasing haemoglobin levels and improving other iron-related biomarkers, with significantly fewer gastrointestinal adverse events (5.6% vs. 13.9%). Both treatments showed similar efficacy in alleviating anaemia-related symptoms.
population_specificity: Italian women aged 18-50 years diagnosed with iron deficiency anaemia.
effective_dosage: V0355 (80 mg Fe/day) and Ferrograd® (105 mg Fe/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether plasma zinc concentration changes in response to consuming zinc-fortified foods or liquid zinc supplements, not specifically focusing on iron.
results_summary: The study found no significant interaction between groups and study day for plasma zinc concentration. At day 15, the zinc-supplemented group showed a greater mean change in plasma zinc concentration compared to placebo and fortification groups, but no significant differences were observed by day 29.
population_specificity: 132 healthy Senegalese men aged 18 years or older.
effective_dosage: 200 g/d of wheat bread fortified with iron and folic acid (control group); other groups received additional zinc at 7.5 mg or 15 mg as ZnO or 15 mg as ZnSO(4).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of iron supplementation in infant mental and motor development through systematic reviews and meta-analyses of RCTs.
results_summary: The abstract notes a lack of clarity and consensus regarding iron's role in mental and motor development, suggesting mixed or inconclusive evidence. Systematic reviews of RCTs were highlighted as a robust method, but potential biases remain even with this approach.
population_specificity: Infants (early nutrition focus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether riboflavin supplementation could improve hematologic status (specifically hemoglobin levels) in moderately riboflavin-deficient women, with a focus on its interaction with iron status.
results_summary: Riboflavin supplementation significantly improved hemoglobin status, particularly in women with the lowest baseline riboflavin levels. Dietary iron intake and iron absorption remained unchanged, suggesting riboflavin's role in iron utilization rather than absorption.
population_specificity: Moderately riboflavin-deficient women aged 19-25 years in the United Kingdom.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to define iron deficiency anaemia (IDA), outline appropriate diagnostic investigations, and recommend management strategies for different patient populations.
results_summary: The study found that serum ferritin is the most powerful test for iron deficiency, and both upper and lower GI investigations are recommended for diagnosing IDA in specific populations. Iron supplementation is advised for all patients to correct anaemia and replenish body stores, with parenteral iron as an alternative if oral preparations are not tolerated.
population_specificity: Adult men, postmenopausal women, premenopausal women, and post-gastrectomy patients, with specific age and symptom-based criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of zinc supplementation on linear growth in children, including its interaction with iron when co-administered.
results_summary: The study found that zinc supplementation had a significant positive effect on linear growth, particularly when administered alone. Co-administration with iron reduced the effect size compared to zinc alone.
population_specificity: Children under 5 years of age in developing countries.
interactions: Reduced efficacy when zinc was co-administered with iron.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of iron supplementation (with and without folate) on maternal anemia and assess the quality of evidence for these interventions.
results_summary: Daily iron supplementation reduced anemia at term by 73% and iron deficiency anemia by 67%, with moderate-quality evidence. Iron-folate supplementation also reduced anemia by 73% but had non-significant effects on iron deficiency anemia (low-quality evidence). Intermittent supplementation showed no difference compared to daily regimens.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, particularly in contexts where iron deficiency is prevalent.
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of multiple micronutrient supplements versus standard iron-folate supplements on maternal and pregnancy outcomes, including maternal anemia, small-for-gestational age births, and neonatal mortality.
results_summary: The study found no significant benefit of multiple micronutrients over iron-folate for maternal anemia but showed a 9% reduction in small-for-gestational age births. Neonatal mortality risk increased in home births but not in facility-based births.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in developing countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of zinc delivered via liquid supplement versus zinc-fortified complementary food on plasma zinc concentrations in young children.
results_summary: Plasma zinc concentration significantly increased in children receiving zinc supplementation but not in those receiving zinc-fortified food. No significant changes were observed in the control or fortified food groups.
population_specificity: 137 young Senegalese children aged 9-17 months.
effective_dosage: 6 mg Zn per day (either in liquid supplement or fortified porridge).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of iron in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and assess the potential benefits of iron supplementation in patients with PAH.
results_summary: Iron deficiency is prevalent in idiopathic and heritable PAH, linked to poorer survival and exercise capacity. High hepcidin levels may inhibit iron uptake, and iron status may influence pulmonary circulation and muscle function. Two ongoing studies are investigating iron supplementation's safety and benefits in PAH patients.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic and heritable pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how maternal iron (Fe) and zinc (Zn) supplementation during pregnancy affects nonheme iron absorption and iron status in offspring, and whether these effects depend on maternal Fe and Zn status at conception.
results_summary: Zn supplementation in adequately nourished dams increased offspring liver iron concentration but compromised postnatal body weight, while Zn supplementation in deficient dams decreased offspring hepcidin expression. Fe and Fe+Zn supplementation in adequately nourished dams reduced ferroportin levels in pup intestines.
population_specificity: Pregnant rats and their offspring.
effective_dosage: Fe (27 mg/wk), Zn (4.5 mg/wk), or Fe+Zn (27 mg Fe + 4.5 mg Zn/wk).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of iron interventions in global health initiatives, particularly focusing on maternal and neonatal health, child nutrition, and fortification.
results_summary: The study highlights the significant impact of iron deficiency anemia on maternal and child health but notes that iron supplementation in pregnancy lacks strong programmatic support and evidence for high-priority clinical outcomes. It suggests that integrating iron nutrition into antenatal care and prioritizing iron-promoting actions could advance maternal and neonatal health.
population_specificity: Women, children, pregnant women, and neonates.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the dose-response relationship between maternal hemoglobin levels and two prenatal iron supplements (30 mg Fe + UNIMMAP vs. 60 mg Fe + folic acid) to determine the most effective dose for preventing maternal anemia.
results_summary: The study found that both supplements showed similar hemoglobin dose responses, with UNIMMAP achieving comparable effects with half the iron dose of IFA. However, micronutrient supplementation did not significantly prevent anemia, which remained highly prevalent, partly due to physiologic hemodilution.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in rural Burkina Faso, 43.2% of whom were anemic at inclusion.
effective_dosage: 30 mg Fe + UNIMMAP or 60 mg Fe + folic acid, taken as directly observed tablets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Helicobacter pylori eradication affects iron stores in non-iron-deficient children.
results_summary: The study found no overall effect of H. pylori eradication on iron stores, but children who had their infection eradicated showed a significantly larger increase in serum ferritin compared to those who remained infected. The effect was more pronounced in those infected with cytotoxin-associated gene product A-negative strains.
population_specificity: Asymptomatic, non-iron-deficient children aged 3-10 years with H. pylori infection in the contiguous United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of high-dose intravenous iron in treating iron deficiency, iron deficiency anemia, and blood loss across various clinical conditions.
results_summary: The study found that intravenous iron is effective for rapid iron repletion, superior to oral iron in many cases, and particularly beneficial in chronic disease-related anemia. New formulations allow high-dose administration in single infusions, improving treatment efficiency.
population_specificity: Patients with nondialysis-dependent chronic kidney disease, inflammatory bowel disease, obstetrics, menorrhagia, and cancer-related anemia.
effective_dosage: 1500 mg in chronic kidney disease, up to 3600 mg in inflammatory bowel disease, 510 mg (ferumoxytol), 15 mg/kg (ferric carboxymaltose), and 20 mg/kg (iron isomaltoside 1000).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the influence of Helicobacter pylori infection on markers of iron stores and evaluate the efficacy of iron supplementation alongside eradication therapy.
results_summary: The study found no difference in H. pylori cure rates between children receiving iron supplementation and those receiving placebo, indicating iron supplementation did not enhance eradication efficacy. Adverse events from study medications were mostly mild or absent.
population_specificity: Asymptomatic children aged 3 to 11 with H. pylori infection in El Paso, Texas.
effective_dosage: 6 weeks of iron supplementation (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming iron-fortified fruit juice improves iron status in menstruating women with iron-deficiency anemia.
results_summary: The iron-fortified fruit juice significantly improved iron parameters, including increased ferritin, transferrin saturation, hematocrit, MCV, and Hb, while decreasing transferrin, sTfR, and ZnPP. Serum iron levels did not change.
population_specificity: Menstruating women
effective_dosage: 18 mg Fe/day (100% RDA) via 500 ml/day of iron-fortified fruit juice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of oral bovine lactoferrin supplementation in reducing acne lesions in individuals with mild to moderate facial acne vulgaris.
results_summary: The study found a mean reduction in inflammatory, non-inflammatory, and total acne lesion counts after 8 weeks of supplementation, with 76.9% of subjects showing improvement. No lactoferrin-related adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Adolescents and young adults (aged 17.5 ± 3.8 years) with mild to moderate facial acne vulgaris.
effective_dosage: Chewable tablet formulation of bovine lactoferrin twice daily (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether weekly iron supplementation with ferrous sulphate heptahydrate (FeSO4) improves hemoglobin (Hb) and hematocrit (Ht) values and reduces anemia prevalence in 5-year-old children.
results_summary: Iron supplementation significantly increased mean Hb and Ht values (p < 0.0001) and reduced anemia prevalence from 48.0% to 26.0% in the intervention group, while the placebo group showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: 5-year-old pre-school children (n = 135) from a public school in northeast Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether iron supplementation during infancy leads to long-term cognitive improvements in children by age 9.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in cognitive performance or school achievement at age 9 between children who received iron supplementation in infancy and those who did not. Iron supplementation did not result in long-term cognitive benefits.
population_specificity: 560 children aged 4-6 months at the start of the study, followed up at age 9.
effective_dosage: Daily supplementation for 6 months (specific dosage not mentioned in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of rHuEPOα therapy, supplemented with Iron, folic acid, and Vitamin E, on reducing transfusion needs and improving outcomes in severely premature infants.
results_summary: The study found that rHuEPOα therapy, combined with Iron supplementation, significantly reduced transfusion needs and increased ventilation-free days in premature infants, though NICU stay remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Premature neonates with birth weight <1250 g and gestational age <30 weeks.
effective_dosage: Iron supplementation was administered, but specific dosage and frequency were not detailed in the abstract.
study_duration: The intervention duration was not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the modifying effects of household wealth on responses to iron/folic acid and multiple micronutrient supplements in pregnancy on newborn anthropometry and perinatal mortality.
results_summary: Iron/folic acid significantly increased gestation duration by 0.41 weeks, reduced pre-term birth by 45%, and reduced early neonatal mortality by 90% compared to folic acid alone. These effects were most pronounced in women from the poorest households, with no significant effects observed in wealthier households.
population_specificity: Pregnant women from poor households in rural northwestern China.
effective_dosage: Not specified (iron/folic acid or multiple micronutrients with a recommended allowance of 15 vitamins and minerals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the frequency of bleeding and treatment efficacy in patients with von Willebrand disease (VWD) characterized by increased VWF clearance, focusing on iron supplementation among other treatments.
results_summary: Iron supplementation was used to manage menorrhagia in some patients, with 20% of VWD-VI and 89% of C1130F mutation carriers requiring consultation/treatment for menorrhagia. The study found desmopressin effective for minor procedures, while major surgeries required factor VIII/VWF concentrates.
population_specificity: 60 heterozygous patients with VWD Vicenza (R1205H mutation) and 23 with C1130F mutation, characterized by increased VWF clearance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two different multi-micronutrient supplement (MMS) preparations, including iron, versus iron-folic acid supplementation on fetal loss and under-2-years child mortality.
results_summary: The study found that both 1xRDA and 2xRDA MMS preparations marginally reduced fetal loss risk but did not reduce under-2-years mortality. There was a marginally negative effect on mortality between 92-365 days of age for both MMS preparations.
population_specificity: 2,100 pregnant women in Guinea-Bissau.
effective_dosage: 1xRDA and 2xRDA MMS preparations (14 vitamins and minerals, including iron).
study_duration: Duration of pregnancy (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily intake of beef as a complementary food improves linear growth velocity and micronutrient status (including iron) compared to a fortified cereal supplement in young children.
results_summary: The study compared beef and cereal supplements but did not report specific iron-related outcomes in the abstract. It assessed biomarkers of iron status at 18 months, but results were not detailed.
population_specificity: Infants aged 6-18 months in low-resource settings (Guatemala, Pakistan, DRC, Zambia) with stunting rates ≥20%.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether iron stores, measured by serum ferritin concentration, could predict response to psychostimulants in children with ADHD.
results_summary: Lower serum ferritin levels were inversely correlated with baseline ADHD symptom severity and the optimal dose of amphetamine needed for treatment, suggesting iron status may influence ADHD symptoms and psychostimulant response. Previously medicated children showed a stronger association between ferritin levels and symptom severity.
population_specificity: 6- to 14-year-old children with ADHD (83% male).
effective_dosage: Not specified for iron (study focused on ferritin levels, not supplementation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prenatal iron/folic acid supplementation affects children's intellectual and motor functioning later in life.
results_summary: Prenatal iron/folic acid supplementation was associated with improved intellectual functioning (working memory, inhibitory control) and fine motor skills in children, particularly in an iron-deficient population. No significant benefits were observed for iron/folic acid/zinc or multiple micronutrient groups compared to the control.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their children (aged 7-9 years at follow-up) in rural Nepal, an area with prevalent iron deficiency.
effective_dosage: Daily iron/folic acid, iron/folic acid/zinc, or multiple micronutrients (exact dosages not specified in abstract).
study_duration: From early pregnancy through 3 months postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of intravenous iron sucrose and iron dextran on cytokine activation, reactive oxygen species generation, and oxidative stress in hemodialysis patients and healthy controls.
results_summary: The study found that both iron sucrose and iron dextran increased pro-inflammatory cytokines and reactive oxygen species, with more pronounced effects in ESRD patients. Iron sucrose resulted in higher non-transferrin bound iron levels compared to iron dextran, but both compounds produced similar oxidative stress and cytokine activation.
population_specificity: Ten end-stage renal disease (ESRD) patients on hemodialysis and four age- and sex-matched healthy controls.
effective_dosage: 100 mg of each IV iron product administered over 5 minutes.
study_duration: Single dose with a 2-week washout between products.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether elite athletes experience iron deficiency (ID) due to physical extremes and whether recovery periods sufficiently replenish iron reserves.
results_summary: The study found that 27% of athletes had absolute ID and 70% had functional ID at the end of the season. Recuperation led to slight increases in ferritin levels but was insufficient to fully normalize iron stores, with 14% of athletes showing persistent ID.
population_specificity: 20 elite rowing athletes and 10 professional soccer players.
study_duration: Assessed at end of competitive season, after recuperation, and during pre-season training (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of iron combined with retinol supplementation on iron status, IL-2 levels, and lymphocyte proliferation in anemic pregnant women.
results_summary: Iron supplementation (alone or combined with retinol and folic acid) significantly improved iron status (Hb, plasma iron, ferritin) and immune markers (IL-2 levels, lymphocyte proliferation), with the greatest improvements seen in the group receiving iron, retinol, and folic acid.
population_specificity: 186 anemic pregnant women with hemoglobin levels between 80-110 g/L.
effective_dosage: 60 mg iron as ferrous sulfate daily, with some groups also receiving 0.4 mg folic acid and/or 2.0 mg retinol.

study_goal: To compare body iron stores at birth between term small-for-gestational age (SGA) infants and appropriate-for-gestational age (AGA) infants.
results_summary: Term SGA infants had lower cord serum ferritin levels compared to AGA infants, indicating lesser total iron stores at birth. No correlation was found between maternal and neonatal iron parameters, and serum ferritin levels at 4 weeks were similar in both groups.
population_specificity: Term infants (≥37 weeks gestation) with birth weight ≥1.5 kg, including SGA and AGA infants.
study_duration: Measurements taken at birth and at 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the frequency and severity of anemia in IBD patients from referral centers and gastroenterologic practices versus the general population, and assess supplementation therapy.
results_summary: Anemia was more prevalent in IBD patients from referral centers (28.8%) compared to gastroenterologic practices (12.9%) and healthy controls (3.4%). Supplementation therapy (iron, vitamin B12, folic acid) was performed in 40-43% of anemic IBD patients.
population_specificity: IBD patients (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis) from tertiary referral centers and gastroenterologic practices, compared to healthy blood donors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether targeted iron substitution could prevent anemia and enhance donor return rates in premenopausal female blood donors with iron deficiency.
results_summary: The study found that iron supplementation significantly increased serum ferritin levels (from 7.12 to 25.2 ng/ml) and resolved symptoms like fatigue, hair loss, and nail breakage. No cases of anemia occurred, and 60% of participants completed the program and donated blood again.
population_specificity: Premenopausal female blood donors aged ≤50 with adequate hemoglobin levels but serum ferritin ≤10 ng/ml.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between IL-6, hepcidin, and iron after prolonged exercise and assess the effect of carbohydrate ingestion on post-exercise hepcidin levels.
results_summary: Plasma IL-6 and hepcidin increased post-exercise but returned to baseline by 24 hours. Carbohydrate ingestion reduced IL-6 but did not affect hepcidin or iron levels, suggesting exercise-induced hepcidin upregulation may contribute to iron deficiency in athletes.
population_specificity: Nine healthy, trained males
study_duration: Single exercise session (120 min run + 5 km time trial) with 24-hour follow-up

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and use of iron supplementation therapy for treating anemia in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: Intravenous iron was found to reduce ESA dose requirements and improve hemoglobin maintenance in hemodialysis patients, while oral iron was less effective due to impaired absorption from elevated hepcidin levels. Iron deficiency was indicated by serum ferritin and transferrin saturation levels below 450 pmol/l and 20%, respectively.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), particularly those on hemodialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of lavender essential oil (LEO) on glioblastoma (GBM) cell proliferation, migration, and oxidative stress.
results_summary: LEO impaired GBM cell proliferation and migration and reduced oxidative stress in U87 cells. Terpinen-4-ol, a component of LEO, replicated these effects.
population_specificity: U87 glioblastoma cell model (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of lavender essential oil therapy in managing pain and anxiety after cesarean delivery.
results_summary: Lavender aromatherapy significantly reduced pain at rest, pain after mobilization, and anxiety levels compared to placebo, with no reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: 100 women undergoing cesarean delivery under spinal anesthesia.
study_duration: Five months (study duration; intervention length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of lavender oil in reducing social anxiety among first-year college students.
results_summary: The study found that lavender oil significantly reduced social anxiety levels, with a mean difference score of 16.37 and a statistically significant reduction in anxiety (P < 0.001). Post-test results showed 85% of students had no anxiety compared to 70% in the pretest.
population_specificity: First-year college students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lavender essential oil (LEO) could suppress tetracycline resistance (tet) genes and modulate gut microbiota in black soldier fly larvae exposed to oxytetracycline.
results_summary: LEO reduced tet gene abundance by 46.67% and enriched beneficial microorganisms while suppressing pathogens. It also modified fungal composition and nutrient pathways, promoting a more integrated and resilient gut microbiota.
population_specificity: Black soldier fly larvae (Hermetia illucens)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antimicrobial activity of lavender-water extract in treating water contaminated with harmful microorganisms.
results_summary: The study found that lavender-water biocide achieved a 59.09% inhibition rate of pathogenic microorganisms in water after 60 minutes of treatment, demonstrating significant antimicrobial activity. Lavender was more effective than garlic-methanol biocide under the same conditions.
population_specificity: Aquatic ecosystem (river water)
